Sorry I haven't contributed more to the thread I started. I will be trying =
to benchmark NEAT 
against GE over the next few weeks. I will try and post =
my methodology but I am not a 
researcher (I am a professional developer) s=
o bear with me.

Really why I am interested in either NEAT or GE is that I =
want to use it for creating a library 
of behaviours that games developers =
can use in their games. The idea is to develop a set 
of behaviours such as=
 seek, hide, tag, etc. using either NEAT or GE. Then give these to 
develop=
ers so that they can use them in conjunction with their own decision tree l=
ogic.

Hopefully this will give developers a palette of behaviours to choos=
e from thus simplifying 
their decision trees and shortening the developmen=
t process. I see this as a middle road 
between completely evolving an AI a=
nd crafting one by hand.

My first choice is to use NEAT as I am most famil=
iar with it. But if the grammar produced 
by GE isn't extremely large then =
GE might be superior, as I like the idea of evolving a 
grammar then allowi=
ng the developers to calibrate the constants in the grammar using 
another =
algorithm (probably GA) to refine it for new proprietary 3d environments. M=
eaning 
they don't have to be exposed to the evolutionary algorithm itself.=


Shane



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wr=
ote:
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek James" <djames@> wrote:
> >
> =
> On Sat, Oct 11, 2008 at 3:14 PM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@> wrote:
> > >=
 I understand that "hierarchical, modular, and formalized" are
> > > someti=
mes viewed as advantages for Grammatical Encoding (a similar
> > > argument=
 is also made for L-systems, which is also grammatical).
> > > While these =
are clearly properties you want in a programming language,
> > > are these =
really good things for a genetic encoding? The challenge
> > > with encodin=
gs is not only for them to theoretically express all
> > > possible procedu=
res, but also to induce a nicely coupled (smooth)
> > > search space. It se=
ems that the space induced by a strictly modular
> > > and hierarchical enc=
odings is unlikely to be smooth, leading to
> > > brittleness. You can have=
 things like a massive new module being
> > > doubled in one shot (which wo=
uld usually be a mess, like being born
> > > with two heads) or a change at=
 one level of the hierarchy breaking the
> > > rest of it entirely.
> > 
> =
> And yet if evolution stumbles upon a module whose usefulness stems
> > fr=
om multiple occurrences, how else would this be accomplished? If we
> > wan=
t artificial encodings to be able to produce something like a
> > mammalian=
 brain, aren't they necessarily going to incorporate
> > hierarchy and modu=
larity?
> > 
> 
> Derek, you probably know some of my thoughts on hierarchy=
 and
> modularity from discussions we've had in person, but to summarize
> =
briefly, while I agree wholeheartedly that both are important
> properties =
observed in phenotypes, the question is how did they get
> there?  
> 
> As=
 some people probably recall me pointing out before, nature does not
> disc=
over one leg, realize it's a good idea, and then duplicate it
> somewhere e=
lse.  Both legs are discovered simultaneously as an
> elaboration of a pree=
xisting bilaterally symmetric convention.  In
> general, I believe that mos=
t modules and hierarchy are the result of
> such elaboration on previously =
established conventions, rather than
> from the duplication of already-exis=
ting modules.
> 
> If an evolutionary algorithm could take a phenotypic mod=
ule and
> duplicate it easily, much of its offspring would be monstrous
> a=
malgamations.  Nature does not generally tinker by simply duplicating
> mod=
ules willy-nilly.   
> 
> Joe Reisinger and I wrote a position paper on thi=
s argument back in
> 2004 called "Exploiting Morphological Conventions for =
Genetic Reuse."
>  It's still available here:
> 
> http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/=
pub-view.php?PubID=3D152
> 
> I can tell you that when I presented the idea=
s in this paper at the
> GECCO workshop in which it appeared, I recall the =
audience found it
> controversial.  A number of people in the audience seem=
ed to react
> especially strongly to my claim that "nature is not an engine=
er." 
> Admittedly, I knew this assertion would draw a reaction, but then
>=
 again, it's perfectly true.  If we try to bend evolution to act like a
> g=
ood computer scientist, it may be akin to forcing an artist to think
> like=
 an engineer.  While the concepts of engineering and computer
> science suc=
h as modularity and hierarchy are naturally appealing to us
> as computer s=
cientists and engineers, their traditional engineering
> conception is not =
necessarily the right perspective for harnessing
> evolution (even if they =
are byproducts of it).  Evolution is more a
> tinkerer than top-down (or ev=
en bottom-up) designer and its modules
> most often result from elaboration=
s of regularities that already exist. 
> 
> ken
>
